steps.title: â€œType shiâ€ stems from African American Vernacular English (AAVE).
steps.content: â€œType shiâ€ stems from African American Vernacular English (AAVE). While the exact origin of â€œtype shiâ€ is unknown, the phrase became popular in the early 2000s, mainly due to its use in rap and hip-hop songs. â€œTypeâ€ is another way of saying â€œkind ofâ€ or â€œlike thatâ€ in AAVE, while â€œshiâ€ is slang for â€œs***.â€ From the mid to late 2000s, Gen Zers started using â€œtype shiâ€ on social media (especially TikTok), which further solidified the phrase in casual speech. Famous YouTuber and Twitch Streamer Duke Dennis is known for saying â€œtype s***â€ a lot. â€œType S***â€ is a popular trap song by Future, Metro Boomin, Travis Scott, and Playboi Carti, with over 120,000 TikTok videos using the audio.

steps.title: Reply with an emoji or Tapback to confirm you heard them.
steps.content: Reply with an emoji or Tapback to confirm you heard them. When youâ€™re struggling to come up with a response, a heart or thumbs up is a great way to let the other person know you got their message. To send a Tapback, tap and hold onto their message, and click on the heart or thumbs up button in the row of reactions.
